articles.headline: Obama Condemns Iran’s Iron Fist Against Protests
articles.snippet: The president hardened his tone toward the Iranian government, but he has limited tools for bringing pressure to bear on it.
articles.abstract: The president hardened his tone toward the Iranian government, but he has limited tools for bringing pressure to bear on it.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama hardened his tone toward Iran on Tuesday, condemning the government for its crackdown against election protesters and accusing Iran’s leaders of fabricating charges against the United States.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: On Nixon Tapes, Ambivalence Over Abortion, Not Watergate
articles.snippet: Newly disclosed tapes recorded in the Oval Office in 1973 shed light on an intense moment in American history.
articles.abstract: Newly disclosed tapes recorded in the Oval Office in 1973 shed light on an intense moment in American history.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  On Jan. 22, 1973, when the Supreme Court struck down laws criminalizing abortion in Roe v. Wade, President Richard M. Nixon made no public statement. But the next day, newly released tapes reveal, he privately expressed ambivalence.

articles.headline: Behind the Scenes, Fed Chief Advocates Bigger Role
articles.snippet: Ben Bernanke has been a forceful proponent of giving the Fed a larger role in regulating the economy.
articles.abstract: Ben Bernanke has been a forceful proponent of giving the Fed a larger role in regulating the economy.

articles.headline: As China Stirs Economy, Some See Protectionism
articles.snippet: One part of China’s effort — limits on the export of certain raw materials — has drawn a formal complaint by the U.S. to the World Trade Organization.
articles.abstract: One part of China’s effort — limits on the export of certain raw materials — has drawn a formal complaint by the U.S. to the World Trade Organization.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG  China has begun a concerted effort to keep its export economy humming, even as demand for its goods has plummeted with the global downturn.

articles.headline: Spate of Attacks Tests Iraqi City and U.S. Pullout
articles.snippet: As the withdrawal date for American troops nears, a string of attacks in Falluja are an ominous sign.
articles.abstract: As the withdrawal date for American troops nears, a string of attacks in Falluja are an ominous sign.
articles.lead_paragraph: FALLUJA, Iraq  Falluja was supposed to be a success story, not a cautionary tale.

articles.headline: Discounts Have Restaurants Eating Own Lunch
articles.snippet: Heavy discounting at casual dining restaurants is leading to tensions between independent franchisees and the corporate officers who control the brands, menus, advertising and strategy.
articles.abstract: Heavy discounting at casual dining restaurants is leading to tensions between independent franchisees and the corporate officers who control the brands, menus, advertising and strategy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Consumers brave enough to pull out their wallets in this economy have grown accustomed to fire sales on every kind of merchandise, from fancy dresses to gas-guzzling cars. Now, add another item to the list: the casual restaurant meal.

articles.headline: Citigroup Has a Plan to Fatten Salaries
articles.snippet: The plan is a test for the Obama administration, which wants to limit compensation at companies that have received federal bailouts.
articles.abstract: The plan is a test for the Obama administration, which wants to limit compensation at companies that have received federal bailouts.
articles.lead_paragraph: After all those losses and bailouts, rank-and-file employees of Citigroup are getting some good news: their salaries are going up.

articles.headline: Despite Recession, High Demand for Skilled Labor
articles.snippet: Employers are begging for specially skilled applicants in fields like critical care nursing and geology.
articles.abstract: Employers are begging for specially skilled applicants in fields like critical care nursing and geology.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just as the recession began, Chris McGrary, a manager at the Cianbro Corporation, set out to hire 80 “experienced” welders. Only now, 18 months later, is he completing the roster.

articles.headline: Cable TV’s Big Worry: Taming the Web
articles.snippet: The heads of the media conglomerates have made protecting cable TV from the ravages of the Internet a top priority.
articles.abstract: The heads of the media conglomerates have made protecting cable TV from the ravages of the Internet a top priority.
articles.lead_paragraph: Like newspaper owners, media moguls are looking for new ways to protect their investment from the ravages of the Internet. And, as with the newspaper industry, the answer remains elusive.

articles.headline: Deep in Bedrock, Clean Energy and Quake Fears
articles.snippet: AltaRock Energy will drill near San Francisco using a method that has caused earthquakes elsewhere.
articles.abstract: AltaRock Energy will drill near San Francisco using a method that has caused earthquakes elsewhere.
articles.lead_paragraph: BASEL, Switzerland  Markus O. Häring, a former oilman, was a hero in this city of medieval cathedrals and intense environmental passion three years ago, all because he had drilled a hole three miles deep near the corner of Neuhaus Street and Shafer Lane.

articles.headline: Tentative Settlement at The Boston Globe
articles.snippet: The New York Times Company and the paper’s largest union agreed to cuts in wages, benefits and job security.
articles.abstract: The New York Times Company and the paper’s largest union agreed to cuts in wages, benefits and job security.
articles.lead_paragraph: After months of bitter struggle that included a threat to shut down The Boston Globe, the New York Times Company and the paper’s largest union reached a tentative contract settlement on Tuesday night, with employees agreeing to significant cuts in wages, benefits and job security.

articles.headline: Iran Stepping Up Effort to Quell Election Protest
articles.snippet: The Iranian leadership has begun casting anyone who disputes the presidential election result as an enemy of the nation.
articles.abstract: The Iranian leadership has begun casting anyone who disputes the presidential election result as an enemy of the nation.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEHRAN  Iranian officials stepped up efforts to crush the remaining resistance to a disputed presidential election on Wednesday, as security forces overwhelmed a small group of protesters with brutal beatings, tear gas and gunshots in the air. Intelligence agents shut down an office of a defeated presidential candidate, saying it was a “headquarters for a psychological war.”
articles.byline: By Nazila Fathi and Michael Slackman

articles.headline: Mysteries Remain After Governor Admits an Affair
articles.snippet: In a rambling news conference, Mark Sanford apologized for having an affair, dampening his prospects for a national political career.
articles.abstract: In a rambling news conference, Mark Sanford apologized for having an affair, dampening his prospects for a national political career.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLUMBIA, S.C.  Gov. Mark Sanford of South Carolina said Wednesday that he had been having an extramarital affair with a woman in Argentina for the last year, ending the mystery surrounding his disappearance over Father’s Day weekend and considerably dampening his prospects for a national political career.
articles.byline: By Robbie Brown and Shaila Dewan
